text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Richard Holbrooke's appointment revives the interest of the Americans in the Cyprus problem.
- Efforts by opposition parties Akel (communist) and Diko (centre-right) to forge an alliance ahead of the presidential elections next year fall through.

- Claims that British AIDS sufferer Janette Pink infected a Cypriot bus driver with the virus are untrue, an AIDS specialist tells court during the trial of Cypriot Pavlos Georgiou. Pink has accused Georgiou of giving her the virus.
- Turkey denies charges its warplanes violated Cyprus's airspace on Tuesday.
- The British and the Americans are preparing a document to bridge the differences between the Greek and Turkish Cypriot sides on the Cyprus problem.
- Holbrooke's appointment as Washington's envoy on the Cyprus problem sends a decisive message of determination and intent.
- Akel and Diko will go their own way in next year's presidential elections.
- Police make disclosures to court on organised crime in Cyprus. A man who survived a murder attempt in Larnaca last week names his would-be killers. Two men are under arrest.
